title: Vegetable Garden
description: The Campbell family, who owned Duntroon Estate, allotted a house and a parcel of land to each married worker on the estate. Blundells Cottage is the only remaining workers' cottage from that time period. In addition to the provision of lodgings, the Campbells granted workers a free half day on Saturdays to tend their gardens. Subsequent families also grew their own food for themselves and for sale. This garden bed represents the approximate site of Alice Oldfield's garden. The Sainsbury Family (in the 60s) grew potatoes and watermelons on the western side of the house.

mediaItems.caption: The vegetable garden at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The vegetable garden at Blundells Cottage.

title: Bread Oven
description: This exterior oven was built in an extension to the Cottage completed in 1888, the same year the eighth Blundell child was born. Flora would use this oven to bake bread for the family three times a week. On the other days, the family would eat damper. When she wasn't using it, Flora would let her neighbours, such as Mrs. Mayo, bake for their own families. Thousands of years ago, the local Aboriginal people would also make a type of bread or cake from ground Bogong Moths and Kangaroo Grass.

mediaItems.caption: The bread oven at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The bread oven at Blundells Cottage.

title: Ship's Tank
description: Once these tanks had served their purpose on board a ship, they were often purchased by rural households to be used as water tanks. The Blundells had three onsite, which they filled from the Molonglo River. They were eventually dumped in the lake bed as part of the clean-up and landscaping during the construction of Lake Burley Griffin.

mediaItems.caption: Ship's tank used as a water tank.
mediaItems.altText: One of the water tanks at Blundells Cottage.

title: Rainwater Tank
description: The ubiquitous Australian rainwater tank, used to catch water running off the roof, saved at least some trips to the river. This is the approximate location of the last tank onsite during Alice Oldfield's residence.

mediaItems.caption: The rainwater tank at the front of Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The rainwater tank at the front of Blundells Cottage.

title: Fence line
description: These posts represent the fenceline of the northern boundary of George Blundell's 125 acre leasehold. Property boundary fences were mandatory from the time of the Robertson Land Act of 1864. The Blundell children had to walk a long way to school when the St John's government school nearby closed and was re-opened at Narrabunda. Internal fencing of paddocks became more common in the 1880s, but was not a statutory requirement.

title: 1888 Extension Line
description: There is a visible change in the stone construction of the building on the western side. The southern section (with the chimney) is an extension built in 1888 and the stonework is not as refined as that of the original building. Note the profile of the original section - it is identical to the crofters cottages of western Scotland, where the original design and the stonemasons themselves came from.

mediaItems.caption: The side of Blundells Cottage showing the difference between the extension and the original building.
mediaItems.altText: The side of Blundells Cottage showing the difference between the extension and the original building.

mediaItems.caption: Closeup showing the detail of the original stonework.
mediaItems.altText: Closeup showing the detail of the original stonework.

mediaItems.caption: Closeup showing the less-refined detail of the extension stonework.
mediaItems.altText: Closeup showing the less-refined detail of the extension stonework.

mediaItems.caption: A Crofters Cottage in Onich, Scotland.
mediaItems.credit: Wikicommons, unknown author, 1903, Leonard A Lauder collection of Raphael Tuck & Sons Postcards
mediaItems.altText: A Crofters Cottage in Onich, Scotland.

title: Artemisia Plant
description:
Wormwood (Tree wormwood or Artemisia arborescens) were a popular plant in the 19th and 20th century because their leaves repel clothes insects.

mediaItems.caption: Closeup on wormwood plant out the front of the Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: Closeup on wormwood plant out the front of the Cottage.

title: Lake Burley Griffin
description: Did you know that Lake Burley Griffin is man-made? It was completed in 1963 after the Molonglo River was dammed. Imagine the changes the Aboriginal people would have experienced in the landscape after white settlement of the area. Can you imagine the Lake not being here?

mediaItems.caption: Blundells Cottage in the foreground and the High Court under construction in 1978 in the background.
mediaItems.credit: Photo 006158, ACT Heritage Library, Canberra Times Collection
mediaItems.altText: Blundells Cottage in the foreground and the High Court under construction in 1978 in the background.

mediaItems.caption: The Administrative Building (later John Gorton Building) and the National Library of Australia in the background, 1983.
mediaItems.credit: Photo 000210, ACT Heritage Library, Canberra Times Collection
mediaItems.altText: The Administrative Building (later John Gorton Building) and the National Library of Australia in the background, 1983.

title: Acknowledgement of Country
description: Families have occupied this land for thousands of years, long before the Cottage was constructed. The NCA acknowledges the traditional custodians of this land and pays their respects to their elders past, present and emerging.

mediaItems.altText: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

title: Robert Campbell 1769â€“1846 - Founder of Duntroon
description: Originally from Scotland, Robert Campbell arrived in Sydney on the Hunter in 1798 as a wealthy merchant. When his ship The Sydney was wrecked, he was compensated in the form of rich, grazing land on the Limestone Plains, now Canberra. He built Duntroon House on his large Duntroon Estate in 1830, the first limestone cottage in the region. By 1860, George Campbell, Robert's son, and his wife Marrianne Campbell had moved into Duntroon House. They started a major building program on the estate which included workman's cottages for the newly arrived immigrant workers from Britain. Blundells Cottage was made from stone quarried from Black Mountain and Mount Ainslie and was based upon crofters cottages of Western Scotland.

mediaItems.caption: Works undertaken on the slab shed outbuilding by traditional craftsman, Myles Gostelow.
mediaItems.altText: Works undertaken on the slab shed outbuilding by traditional craftsman, Myles Gostelow

title: Cubby
description: During some time in the early 20th century, the verandah of the Cottage was enclosed to create another room. Alice Oldfield would let this room to tenants. The enclosure has since been removed.

mediaItems.caption: A rare photo of the enclosed verandah of the Cottage taken in the 1930s.
mediaItems.altText: A rare photo of the enclosed verandah of the Cottage taken in the 1930s.

title: Kennels
description: There used to be a turkey shed, kennels, haystacks, a small forge, a cow shed and a chicken coop on the ground of Blundells Cottage. Harry Oldfield kept dogs in kennels that have since been removed.

mediaItems.caption: A turkey shed, kennels, haystacks, a small forge, a cow shed and a chicken shed to the right of Blundells Cottage, 1930s.
mediaItems.altText: A turkey shed, kennels, haystacks, a small forge, a cow shed and a chicken shed to the right of Blundells Cottage, 1930s.
